statement.tex: %text If $\ora{a}$ and $\ora{b}$ are two vectors such that $\vert \ora{a}+\ora{b}\vert=\vert\ora{a}\vert$, then prove that vector $2\ora{a}+\ora{b}$ is perpendicular to vector $\ora{b}$. %

step.context: \begin{align} \ora{a}&=\vector{x_a}{y_a}{z_a} \\ \ora{b}&=\vector{x_b}{y_b}{z_b}, \end{align} \\ %text If $|\ora{a}+\ora{b}|=|\ora{a}|$, and $|\ora{b}|\neq 0$ then is the following correct? %

step.reason: %text If two vectors are perpendicular, their dot product is zero. Alternatively, if two vectors are parallel, their cross product is zero. %

step.context: \begin{align} \ora{a}&=\vector{x_a}{y_a}{z_a} \\ \ora{b}&=\vector{x_b}{y_b}{z_b} \end{align} \\ %text If $|2\ora{a}+\ora{b}|$ is $\perp$ to $\ora{b}$ then is the following correct? %
step.reason: \begin{align} \ora{a}&=\vector{x_a}{y_a}{z_a} \\ \ora{b}&=\vector{x_b}{y_b}{z_b} \end{align} \\ %text $2 \ora{a}+\ora{b}$ is $\perp$ to $\ora{b}$, therefore, % \begin{align} &(2 \ora{a}+\ora{b})\cdot \ora{b}=0 \\ \implies&2\ora{a}\cdot\ora{b}+\ora{b}\cdot\ora{b}=0 \\ \implies&2(x_ax_b+y_ay_b+z_az_b)+x_b^2+y_b^2+z_b^2=0 \end{align} \\ %text Which matches the result derived from condition $|\ora{a}+\ora{b}|=|\ora{a}|$ given in Step 2, thus proving the original problem. %
